titleStmt.title: A great fight at sea, between the English, French, Dutch, and Portugals, neer Gibralterre in the Streights: with the manner of their engagement; the particulars of the fight; and the number of ships sunk and taken by Captain Pen, vice-admirall for the Parliament of England also a bloudy fight in Ireland between the Parliaments forces, commanded by Collonel Axtel, Col. Pretty, Col. Zanchey, and Col. Cooke; and the Irish under the command of Commis. General Dungan. With a list of the colonels, lieutenant-colonels, majors, captains, and the rest of the officers and souldiers, killed and taken prisoners on both sides.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 11 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: A great fight at sea, between the English, French, Dutch, and Portugals, neer Gibralterre in the Streights: with the manner of their engagement; the particulars of the fight; and the number of ships sunk and taken by Captain Pen, vice-admirall for the Parliament of England also a bloudy fight in Ireland between the Parliaments forces, commanded by Collonel Axtel, Col. Pretty, Col. Zanchey, and Col. Cooke; and the Irish under the command of Commis. General Dungan. With a list of the colonels, lieutenant-colonels, majors, captains, and the rest of the officers and souldiers, killed and taken prisoners on both sides.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A GREAT FIGHT AT SEA, Between the Engli≈øh, French, Dutch, and Portugals, neer Gibralterre in the Streights: With the manner of their Engagement; the particulars of the Fight; and the number of Ships ≈øunk and taken by Captain Pen, Vice-Admirall for the Parliament of England
Al≈øo a bloudy Fight in Ireland between the Parliaments Forces, commanded by Collonel Axtel, Col. Pretty, Col. Zanchey, and Col. Cooke; and the Iri≈øh under the command of Commi≈ø. General Dungan.
With a Li≈øt of the Colonels, Lieutenant-colonels, Majors, Captains, and the re≈øt of the Officers and Souldiers, killed and taken pri≈øoners on both ≈øides.
Imprinted at London, for G. ‚Ä¢ amuel, 1651.

div.head: A bloody Fight at Sea, between the Engli≈øh, French, Dutch, and Portugals; the particulars thereof, the number of ≈øhips ≈øunk and taken; and the manner how the Parliaments ≈øhips boarded the French three times, but were ≈øtill repul≈øed and beaten off; but laying them aboard the fourth time, forced them under Decks, killed many, and took divers pri≈øoners.

body.p:
ON the 13. of this in≈øtant (after a tempe≈øtuous ≈øtorm) it plea≈øed God to admit us a fair Gale, and a ≈øea≈øonable calm, untill ≈øuch time that we had coa≈øted neer the point of Gibralterre, where we made a di≈øcovery of the re≈øt of our Fleet under the Conduct of Vice-Admirall Pen; and coming up to them, our Captain was called aboard the Fairfax Frigat, where a Councel of Officers were pre≈øent; and after ≈øome ≈øerious con≈øultation touchin the French and Portugal Fleet in the
Streights, unanimou≈øly re≈øolved to ≈øteer towards that coa≈øt, and fight them; and accordingly on the 14 in≈øtant, we weighed anchor, and after 9 hours ≈øayl came within ≈øight of them; which they perceiving, immediatly prepared to receive Us, opening their port-holes, put forth their Guns, and man'd their Decks; for indeed they were at lea≈øt three to one; being about 33 Sayl, and mo≈øt con≈øi≈øting of tho≈øe Bankers which were the onely Pyrats that had mo≈øt annoy'd the Engli≈øh and Dutch: Our Fleet con≈øi≈øted of but nine ≈øayl, but very re≈øolved men; as appears by the en≈øuing Narrative, viz.

When we came within a league of their Rear. Admirall, Orders were given for each man to make ready to man the Decks, the Gunners and their A≈ø≈øi≈øtants to prepare and open their port-holes; and ≈øo each man according to his place and calling, to endeavour what in him lay to perform that duty and ≈øervice which God had called him unto: This was with great care and prudence ob≈øerved; and immediatly the Red Flag in every ≈øhip was put forth; which being done, the Trumpets ≈øounded, the Marriners ≈øhouted, and ≈øoon after the Canons plaid; for when we came within half a league of them, about 13 of their be≈øt ≈øhips were manned forth, who gave us ≈øeveral broad ≈øides; which Captain Pen perceiving, immediatly made up to them with the Fairfax, the Lyon, the Dolphin, and the George, and gave them eight broad ≈øides; in≈øomuch that the Enemy declined engagement, and would fain have de≈øerted us; but C. Pen keeping clo≈øe up with them to the re≈øt of their ≈øhips, the whole Fleets became engaged; and a bloudy fight en≈øued, which continued for the ≈øpace of two hours, and very gallantly maintained on both ≈øides: For the Lyon laid the French Admiral aboard three times, and was ≈øtill repul≈øed and beaten off; but the fourth time ≈øhe carryed it, and
hailing her clo≈øe, entred the ≈øhip, and put mo≈øt of the men to the ≈øword, for they denied quarter. During this di≈øpute, the valiant Fairfax, and the re≈øt of our Fleet, plyed them clo≈øe with great and ≈ømall ≈øhot, and killed many of them, e≈øpecially the Portugals, who lay the mo≈øt open to out ≈øhot, for they charged their Canon on the out-≈øide of their ≈øhips: In this conflict we ≈øunk 7, and boarded five more; and at la≈øt di≈øpier≈øed the whole Navy, taking about 15 ≈øayl of them; ≈øo that there are not many got off, but ≈øome few Pickroons, which were too ≈øwift for us; but I am confident, they cannot be very ≈øerviceable; for the ≈øhips that we have taken are exceedingly torn, and mo≈øt of the men either killed or wounded; ≈øo re≈øolutely did they fight it out. And truly I may ≈øay, that ≈øuch a mercy never did God be≈øtow upon his poor ≈øervants at Sea, as he hath done upon Us, in giving of Us Victory over our Enemies, and making Us in≈øtrumental for the vanqui≈øhing ≈øuch a formidable pyratical power as the≈øe were, with ≈øo little lo≈ø≈øe; for from the beginning to the ending, we lo≈øt not above 20 men, ≈øome few wounded, and our ≈øhips not much defaced or torn: God grant that we may live to prai≈øe & glorifie the Name of the Lord for this happy deliverance: And likewi≈øe for the many and wonderful deliverances which He hath di≈øpen≈øed to his ≈øervants.

Two Dutch men of War came in to our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance about the middle of the fight; but its conjectur'd, that it was more for their own ends, then for any love they bare to us: however, I ≈øhall cen≈øure charitably; for we have lo≈øt nothing, but they haue gain'd; having by this means inlarg'd their liberty upon the≈øe Coa≈øts.

closer.dateline: From aboard the Dolphin November the 19. 1651.

div.p: From Ireland we have received certain particulars of the manner of the Rebels falling upon the Parliaments Forces at Ro≈ø≈øe, and how ‚Ä¢ hey carried ≈øcaling ladders with them, entred the Town, and took Col. Mackworth, and divers others, pri≈øoners: as appears by the en≈øuing Letter.

body.p:
ON the 19. of this in≈øtant Novemb. 1651. Commi≈ø≈øary Generall Dungan with about 600 Hor≈øe and 800 Foot drew neer to Ro≈øs, nity, g ‚Ä¢ t-over that place about 300 Foot, who marched down to the main Guard of the Town, and ≈øecures them without fire on either ≈øide, ≈øo that the Church and the Block-hou≈øe had not yet received the allarm, that from thence they went to the great gate, and made ≈øhift to break it open to let in their Hor≈øe, that before the Gari≈øon had received alarm both hor≈øe and foot were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Town, from whence they marched down, beating Drums, and ≈øounding Trumpets, by which the Blockhou≈øe and Church received an alarm, and being overpowred, endeavoured onely to keep what they had, and left the Town to their mercy, where they took Col. Markham, Lieu. Abbot, En≈øign Brown, and about 12 private ≈øouldiers: killed about 15 plundered the Town, ≈øparing neither friend nor foe; ran≈øackt the Magazine, ≈øeiz ‚Ä¢ d 12 barrels of powder, match and bullet proportionable; with ≈øome Hats, ≈øtockings, and other good booty. About 9 a clock the next day they ≈øent to the Governour for a ce≈ø≈øation, who finding it would be no wayes prejudicial to him to delay time, he being in want of provi≈øion and accomodation, (they coming ≈øo unexpectedly upon them,) they agreed upon a ce≈ø≈øation, until 7. a Clock next morning. We had no intelligence of the bu≈øine≈øs at Waterford, until 4. a Clock on the Lords day, but upon notice thereof we made out with all the Boats and Ve≈ø≈øels we could procure, and fell down that night within a mile of the Town, and about 10. or 11. a Clock at night the Enemy quitted the place and marched away, having agreed with the Town≈ømen to pay them 400 l. to ≈øave the Town from burning. Since which time we have received intelligence that Col. Cook, and Col. Axtel, with Col. Prette, have given the ≈øame Enemy a repul≈øe, comming upon them in the County of Kildare, fell upon their reare as they were going over a pa≈ø≈øe, put them to the run, pur≈øuing them 4. or 5. miles, about
100. kil ‚Ä¢ d in the pur≈øuit, ≈øome pri≈øoners taken, be≈øides Col. Zankey hath fallen upon the Enemy about Clonmel, took about 50. pri≈øoners: we al≈øo hear that Col. Axtel hath lately had ≈øome ≈øuch ≈øucce≈øs, and ≈øeveral ≈ømall things of this kind, which though it be worth our prai≈øing the Lord for, yet not worth troubling you with unle≈øs places and per≈øons were better known to you; the Enemy took advantage of the Armies being ingaged before Galway and Limrick to make a great deal of bu≈øling and noi≈øe up and down the Country, but the greate≈øt bu≈øine≈øs that they can effect, is to meet at a Randezvouz ≈øome thou≈øands of them together, and have the advantage of intelligence, the Country being ≈øo wholly theirs, that pre≈øently they di≈øper≈øe and vani≈øh away in their Woods and Boggs, upon the lea≈øt intelligence of any party coming towards them.

postscript.head: POSTSCRIPT.
postscript.p: I Had no ≈øooner drawn to a conclu≈øion of my Letter, but immediatly here arrived a Po≈øt, giving a further account of what was before recited; and al≈øo pre≈øenting a Li≈øt to the Governour touching the particulars thereof; a Copy whereof I have hereunto annexed.

list.head: A Li≈øt of the Officers and Souldiers killed and taken pri≈øoners at the ≈øeveral fights at Ro≈øs, Kildare, and Clonmel.
list.item:
Taken of the Parliaments Forces at Ro≈øs.
Col. Markham,
Lieu. Abbot,
En≈øign Brown,
12 Sergeants, Corporals,
and private ≈øouldiers.
12 barrels of powder,
100 skeins of match,
400 weight of bullet, And divers Hats, ≈øtockings, and other rich booty.

Taken of the Rebels by Col. Axtel in Kildare.
1400 Hor≈øe and foot totally routed, under the command of Gen. Dungan.
200 Killed upon the place.
100 in the pur≈øuit.
Col. Kilmock taken
One Lieut. col.
3 Majors.
9 Captains.
20 Lieutenants.
7 Cornets.
9 En≈øigns.
5 Quarterma≈øters.
500 Sergeants, Corporals, and private ≈øouldiers.
600 Armes.
15 Colours, and other rich booty, which they had plundered.
150 more taken by col. Zankey.
